This is not a game.  It is more. What is Mountain? By definition a mountain is a large natural elevation of the earth's surface rising abruptly from the surrounding level. But what does this mean exactly? This is a form of art we ourselves cannot comprehend. It may seem like there is nothing, but a mountain may also be described as a large pile or quantity of something. A great deal. A lot. A profusion. An abundance. There is more to Mountain that we cannot understand. Is it in the trees? Is it in the Mountain itself? Do we wait for the weather to change to ask these questions? The subtle piano melody. The scale. The depth. Maybe it's in the clouds which glide over head. It's a metaphor for life. We see little, but there is much more. So I ask you. Or do you ask? 'Why spend 99 cents on Mountain?' A synonym I can conjure from that sentence follows: 'Why spend 99 cents on the answer to life?' Mountain is the answer to the worlds problems. This is what philosophers have been trying to figure out for years. And these answers are in Mountain. Or is the answer the Mountain itself?  I ask one more time. What is Mountain?  ...  That is for you to answer. Or has it been answered already?  ...  Mountain.

Mountain. A game of true beauty. Let me say, that throughout all seventy-five of all my games, I have NEVER had the chance to become a mountain before. Ever since I was little, I have always wanted to become a professional mountain. But I never got the chance. My parents always told me 'You will never become a mountain, and control the universe, your just a potato'. WELL LOOK AT ME NOW WORLD! I have the power to grow trees and rocks, and I finally feel like a true mountain. This game is revoulutionary, and will truley break the bounds of the video game world! I feel like a new person after playing this game. So will you join me in this journey to become a true mountain?  In all seriousness, all this game is, is you get an all around view of a mountain that is growing and changes during seasons, at least from what i've seen. Also, for some reason, the mountain grows pies and chairs and umbrellas. So thats cool I guess. This game looks like it might actually have a lot of content though. For just a game with a mountain, it looks like there are still a lot of things to see and discover. I don't know. I bought it because, why not I guess. It looks interesting, and random. Plus, i'm going to get a ton of hours because I have no life.  So if your a person who doesn't like looking at mountains, this game is not recommended. I think for a dollar, this game is worth it. But thats just my opinion. I recommend you look at some of the other reviews. Peace Out!

Imagine, if you will.    An Enigma wrapped in mystery sprinkled with oddity.  Now imagine that burrito stuffed into the microwave of your mind and turned to extra-high.  When it comes out, you get Mountain.  Mountain is odd. Like your sister gently massaging your teddy bear.  It's a combination of the shear immense abyss that is your boredom and the expectant anticipation of an eager fawn.  But, like that small brown 4-legged deer, you run the risk of being struck by something you hadn't seen coming. You haven't the time to piece out the details before it ultimately strikes you and you're a crumpled heep of delicious fawn meat and sadness.  Only the car is a giant golfball.  And the fawn is you.   Mountain.

This is literally a rotating mountain. There are no controls. You can look at it from different angles using the mouse. If you press keyboard keys, it plays piano sounds.  This is not a game....I think it's a waste of money and hard drive space.

The sound alone makes this game worth buying in my opinion. Also, it's fun to grab things off the mountain then throw them back into space. A queen sized bed flew into my mountain, so I proceeded to grab the bed and throw it back under the mountain. He is now in a new universe.

A mix of thriller and an mmorpg (potential wow-killer), Mountain covers the life of Mountain, from birth to ultimate annihilation. You take care of Mountain by cleaning it, taking out the trash, and help its singing career, which could save it from the apocolypse. In its lows, fish and fire will rain from the sky but if you are good enough, you can make it rain cold hard cash (coins). If you are the type of player who likes to see things burn, lead Mountain to its demise.   I would only recommend this game to those willing to put a lot of time and effort into grooming your Mountain into success. Those who only play this shortly without allowing this game's amazing depth and quality influence your life indeed are very poor souls. In my personal experience, it takes several hundred hours with this game to fully experience it.  I have only completed Mountain a couple of times in the time I've played, and I hope to get a lot more in the future. I can easily recommend this to anyone willing to sell their souls to the Mountain. 10/10 would sacrifice myself to the mountain again.

I got this game yesterday, I didn't really know what to expect. I launched Mountain. My Mountain came to be. I watched MY Mountain. I laughed, I cried, I loved...I hated. While talking to Mountain through musical notes I discovered annihilation. The first time I saved Mountain with not a moment of hesitation. But then I began to torment Mountain. Letting the object of destruction get closer and closer before saving Mountain. As my hatred grew deeper and deeper for Mountain I once again initiated the annihilation sequence a s , z b this time with the intent of ending Mountain once and for all. The object of destruction was beautiful, a massive pulsating eye, it hungered for Mountain. I watched eagerly as the Eye approached, closer and closer it came. Ohhhh how happy I was to finally see Mountain pay, but then something happened. As the Eye was mere seconds away from ending Mountain as I knew Mountain, a single rogue item drifted on to my screen. A heart. I was astounded. Even after all the terrible hatred I vented at Mountain, Mountain loved me. I quickly mashed my keys in an effort to save Mountain and the screen went blank. Through a miracle I had managed to save Mountain. I do not know what happens if you let the object of destruction hit Mountain and I do not plan to find out, nor do I plan to ever see that wretched Eye again. From this day forward I will never stop caring for Mountain, not for even a second. Many of you hate Mountain, but you have not seen the Mountain I know. Live Mountain, be Mountain, and you too shall know Mountain. All you need is patience.

Do I recommend this game? That's a bad question, because it implies that this thing is a game. Hell, I'm not even sure what it qualifies as. The best description I can give for it is that it's a glorified screensaver. It does nothing except spin, and occasionally the Mountain gets existential. The player can do nothing except watch. I have no clue why critics are obsessing over it. It's a cute concept, but I have literally seen screensavers that do the same thing. The developer notes on the page are straight up lying when they say that it is a game, or that you can play it, or even that it plays itself.  0/10.

It is exactly as it describes in the title, with a little added bonus. Don't expect a huge fun game when buying this. It is a screensaver. A lot of people complain that you aren't actually 'God'. But you are. 'God' gets to sit and watch us mess up the world, without being able to do anything about it. And that is exactly what happens in this game. You watch the mountain grow/be destroyed, and you cannot do a damn thing. I love it. I run it in the background while I work because the nature sounds are nice and enjoyable, and I like to tab to it to check on my mountain. I also keep it on while I sleep, so that I can look at it if I wake up, and it will slowly relax me and I can fall asleep. I love this screensaver 'game' and I feel like people like me will enjoy it too. It's cute and calming. It's also good for panic attacks. Nice job, Devs. :)

I see this game get a lot of hate sometimes, but when you get down at the bottom of it, it does everything it promises: it's an ambient procedural mountain. It's a game that plays itself.  Draw some doodles. Watch the mountain get generated. Watch it get rained on. Watch it get snowed on. Watch it get annihilated by random cosmic activity. Play notes with your keyboard. Sit back and get hypnotized by it for a good 45 minutes. Simple as that.  You buy coffee on your way to class every morning? Skip it for just one day, save the ninety nine cents and try this one out. You'll enjoy it for far longer than an eigh-ounce coffee.

In the days when those old CRT monitors with Windows 3.11 would get super bad screen burn that would never go away? That's what this does, only with a quad core CPU and memory. Pro-tip: typing 'as,zb' (minus the quotes) makes it more interesting.    The game is essentially a simulator of life in a sense. It is about a mountain that is floating in space- yeah, you heard me, SPACE!- and has random things happen to it. It conveys its feelings sometimes and can be mildly interacted with by the player.  It is basically a game that, as said on the store page, should be run in the background. It isn't something you're supposed to sit and stare at and wait for something to happen (I mean, you can if you want, I wouldn't recommend it).  You can play piano notes on your keyboard by hitting the A-K and Z-,(comma) keys, supposing you use a QWERTY style keyboard. Hitting some combinations will unlock different modes such as blood rain, fish rain and constant snow (those are the three they give you on the store page). There might be more, I have no idea really. Hitting these keys can also change the speed of rotation of the mountain.  Randomly, objects such as bowling pins, crates, hearts, steel girders, etc. will fly from space into the mountain. You can click and hold on these items to drag them around the mountain and move their placement. As stated above, your mountain apparently can die. It is dramatic and depressing, because mountain is love, mountain is life.  Lastly, if you hit .(period), the mountain will say random things to you as if it is expressing its feelings. Along with this, it will randomly say things if just left alone for periods of time as well.  Over all, if you're expecting a very interactive, hands-on game, then this  isn't  the game for you. This game is meant to sit there and essentially just be for random events / fun, as if it were a screensaver. I believe it was made for the user to ponder life and their own existence based on the feelings and events that occur to / with the mountain.

If someone gives you this game, immediately unfriend them. They clearly do not have your best interest in mind. This thing, like Adventure Capitalist and a few others here on steam, claims to be a 'background game' - one you can leave running while playing other games and come back to every once in a while, to see what has changed.   However, there are plenty of much better 'games' out there that will not prove to be the biggest waste of CPU that you will ever see. This is not a game. This is an interactive simulation that has this mountain spinning in space. There are asteroids in space, a great nebulous vista, and occasionally junk will accumulate on your mountain. You can make it spin, and if you have an X-Box controller, you can use the A B Y X buttons to produce tones. That is literally all there is to this horrible thing that I cannot at any length call a game.  There is no defending this. Something is not a game simply because of some interactive features. A simulation differs from a game because rather than usually offering the player a challenge or objective, the purpose of a simulation is to simulate and that is all.  If for some reason you still want to interact with this mountain, have at it.

Screw the negative reviewers. Seriously; 'It's a screensaver' - is that all you've got?    Short Version:  Buy it if you want something to take your attention every few minutes, so you can see how it's changed. That's its' beauty - an ever-changing semi-interactive painting on your desktop.  Don't buy it if you want something to grab your attention and hold you for hours. - And don't drop bad reviews on something just because it's exactly what it claims to be!   Proper Review  It's a semi-sentient mountain, of which you are mreely an observer. It's pretty much a digital pet rock that asks psuedo-philosophical questions about it's exsistence, and comments on it's current mood, based on the time of day, season, and / or weather. Sure, it starts with 'You Are God. You Are The Mountain'. But that's not correct, not really. At least, not to me. But that's not a bad thing, either.   IF you go into this, looking at it as an art piece that is designed to run forever in the background (on my second monitor wilst I'm not actively using it to scoop up deals on Steam) - and you realise that there are no 'controls' in this game, then what is there to complain about? It's exactly what it says it is on the tin: you know what you are getting, so WHY are you complaining?    Interactions  The play through begins with it suggesting some themes, and asking you to draw something based on those emotive words. I gather it uses these couple of sketches for it's World generation. Then, the Mountain is 'born', populated with tress, and set spinning for you to watch it.  You can move the camera with the mouse, controls most gamers / CAD designers already find instinctive; (click + drag to rotate in any direction, Mouse scroll to zoom). you can play Music to your mountain, using A-through-K and Z-through-< {less than} to represent notes on a piano. I believe playing melodies speeds up time, and I actually think my mountain sang back to me once 'beeboobeebupboop'.  When the Mountain has something to say, He'll chime at you, then type it out across the top of his screen.   World Generation  as previously mentioned, It uses sketches that you provide to generate your mountain.There is a full gamut of weather here, sun, rain, storms, fog. I haven't seen tornados or the like yet. There is also Seasonal differences... You mountain gets covered in snow, trees lose their leaves in autumn. An entire year cycle seems only to take a few minutes, and days are no more than 1 minute, so you get a wide variety of things going on very quickly.  Trees, I've observed 3 distinct types thus far. They grow and die. New ones seed and sprout. I like that as a feature. There are some little touches, too - like evergreens don't lose their leaves, and thus get a full covering of snow. Things spawn periodically, and crash into your mountain, becoming part of it's landscape. Party hats, Electric fans, Dice, and I have no idea what else yet. My first item spawned inside 5 minutes though. This mechanic provides some variety to what would otherwise be a very serene experience.  The only kind of Fauna I have seen so far is fireflies... merely a flickering light near the trees, at night, during summer.   Universe  Clouds. wow, they look great, they really do... now get them out of my way so I can see my mountain! The other thing I don't really like is your zoom options. Zoom out too far and everything gets hazy, like looking through a mist or fog at something from a distance... which youy are... but you lose a part of the joy, I feel, that could e had by observing your Mountain from afar. Also, I'd like to be able to Zoom In more. I'd love to get up and close with those mushrooms.   Computer Resources  I don't normally mention this, but I will this time, as I think it's relevant, for a 'game' that's supposed to sit on your desktop for most of it's life. It's idling at 250mb RAM (this is fine) and 65% of my CPU. That's more than BIOSHOCK INFINITE Stressed my computer. This interested me enough for me to install it on my old game rig, and when the game puts Mountain in the rain, it lags. (1gb ddr3 gpx card... I said 'old'). This doesn't bother me, unless I'm planning on running a few of my VM's at once, or want to play a game fullscreen (Mountain will let you run another game next to it, unlike most Steam games So in this respect it's more like a tool than a game).    Thoughts  I'd really love to see fauna here - I'd prefer it to random Traffic-cone-Asteroids making my pristine Mountain look like someone tipped out a public rubbish bin all over my lawn****. I'd love to see animals, with varied animations - feeding, grazing, grooming, wandering.... The young getting old and dying? It would be awesome if you could folllow one around and watch it's lifespan over a few minutes, or maybe as much as an hour. This, plus the improved Zoom functionality I mentioned would make this game... better. The Author wants you to connect with Mountain, I think. He wants you to feel that you ARE the mountain. having some kind of life to observe in the game would certainly help with that. I'm thinking fairly in depth, too. I'd love to be able to see opossoms in the trees, deer on the slopes, bears coming out of hibernation... 'and fish in the stream'... hint hint. (Author; you would need a stream!)  Buy it if you want something to take your attention every few minutes, so you can see how it's changed. That's its' beauty - an ever-changing semi-interactive painting on your desktop.  Don't buy it if you want something to grab your attention and hold you for hours. - And don't drop bad reviews on something just because it's exactly what it claims to be!   **** I've learned some things about this game since writing this. One observer compared this 'junk' to the belongings that accumulate over our lives, how most of it is usless, or ultimately meaninless in the course of things, but it's there and it's difficult to make it go away. I like that comparison.  There are 'secrets' in this game. Certain song combo's will produce different effects, such as climate change. i don't recommend this, as (for example) once it started Snowing... it never stopped again. Also, it may ruin some of the 'magic' of this game if you read too many things and come across a spoiler. I regret that this happened to me.  Oh, and an actual trash can just crashed into my Mountain.

It's hard to say whether or not I recommend this game. As the other reviews have said, there is little to this game. Whilst I have racked up some hours playing, I have spent little time interacting with it. I'd say that it would make an excellent interactive screen saver, and I find it difficult to justify it's title as game. But even so, I found myself stangely attached to my mountain. It felt like it was mine, and I wanted it to reflect me. When ever something ugly landed on it, I would take measures to throw it off into space, and at one point I accidently chucked a light bulb away and was shocked at distressed I was at it's loss. The best analogy I can make to this game, is a rock garden, it never changes except by your hand, and lends a sence of clarity and solidarity to the back ground of everything. Even though I have given a very vague review, I have thoroughly enjoyed my time with this game, and ask people to give this game a chance before putting it back down.

Believe it or not, this actually isn't the stupidest game I've ever bought. It's not even the stupidest game I've bought on Steam. I've bought way stupider things than this.  OK, so what is it? It's a 'game' only in the loosest sense. I bought it out of pure morbid curiosity. What I got was..a mountain floating in space. You can move the camera around. You can play music with your keyboard (and if you play certain songs, things can happen). The point, near as I can tell, is...there isn't one. It's a mountain, floating in the middle of space. There's really not much to it. That said, the ambient noises are oddly relaxing, and looking at it I almost can't help but feel ..tranquil. It's rather bizarre. I don't even really want to call this a game, since there's no real controls and no real objective.  But ****, it was 99 cents. I've spent worse dollars than this.

I actually do like the idea of a game that you have very loose control over and mostly just watch. The Sims is like this. My Pokemon Ranch is like this. Many visual novels are like this. I wouldn't exactly call it a game. It's more of a... mountain simulator. A really fun and thought-provoking one, at that.   All you have to do is start it up, leave it open, and go about your other business. Simply peek in from time to time or when you hear a ping announcing that your mountain has a thought to share. A few hours pass and you won't recognize your mountain anymore under piles of fun, but also meaningful stuff that drops onto it. Where are the things coming from? What is their purpose? Is the mountian aware of them? Seems like it is... just like it is aware of the weather, time of day, and its own existence.   Use the keyboard to play it a song, too. Chances are you might trigger some unique weathers/special effects in the process. Or just use one of many guides to help you with that if you're impatient.  It's obvious that Mountain is not a game for everyone. Cerainly not for the instant-gratification crowd that only hungers for action, achievements and kills. And blood splatters on screen. Mountain is peaceful, lazy, laid back, with a touch of philosophy and a sprinkle of peculiar humor added to the mix.   To be honest, I can't imagine working on my computer without Mountain running in the background anymore. Recommended with all my heart.

All these haters showing they don't understand the simple but complex beauty that is Mountain.  Do its thoughts mirror your own? Do they present the opposite ideas? Or do they, in them, show the truth you try so hard to deny?  Does its ambiance calm you? Frustrate you? Terrify you?  Are the relics it collects treasured memories of your past? Are they vague images of your future? Or do they belong to someone else entirely? Am I being facetious with this review? Or do I truly understand what Mountain has to offer? Perhaps the real question is... Do you?
